The '''6-15-99 Club''' was an organization dedicated to assisting the plight of the poor in [[New York City]] in the 1890s. The group formed branch clubs in stores, factories, and banks, expanding at a rapid rate. Employed members were expected to contribute between a penny and two and a half cents to the club daily.<ref name=eight/> William De Hertburn (W. d'H.) Washington, of 145 [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]], and prominent [[Manhattan]] businessmen envisioned raising around $13,000 daily. [[Isidor Straus]], [[Oswald Ottendorfer]], and former New York City mayor [[Franklin Edson]] were proponents of the 6-15-99 Club.<ref>Staff. (January 10, 1894) "New Scheme To Raise Money", ''[[The New York Times]]'', p.9</ref>
==History==
In February 1894 plans were being made to open a 6-15-99 store at [[14th Street (Manhattan)|14th Street]] near [[5th Avenue (Manhattan)|5th Avenue]]. This site was to be used as an office intended to find employment for persons who desired to work. Tasks assigned to job seekers included furniture repair and basic carpentry work. The 6-15-99 Club asked that persons who needed such services, make their requests either at the 14th Street store or at 145 Broadway. An additional store was anticipated to open at [[125th Street (Manhattan)|125th Street]]. By April 1894 there were 270 branches of the 6-15-99 Club.<ref>Staff. (April 8, 1894) "To Make More Money For The Poor", ''[[The New York Times]]'', p.9</ref>
By early 1894 the 6-15-99 Club had secured employment for a number of women who worked making quality garments for children. Sizable retail stores accepted the items manufactured by the women, so that a portion of the work performed by the 6-15-99 Club was self-supporting.<ref name=eight>Staff. (February 1, 1894) "6-15-99 Club Is Growing" ''[[The New York Times]]'', p.3</ref> The free labor bureau of the 6-15-99 Club obtained work for 105 applicants in one week.<ref>"The Unemployed In American Cities", ''[[Quarterly Journal of Economics]]'' (1894) Volume 8, p.467</ref>
According to a periodical from 1894, the 6-15-99 Club was one of seven contemporary and highly advertised funds for the temporary relief of the destitute. The others were those organized by [[Tammany Hall]], New York City officials and employees, the World's Bread Fund, the ''[[New York Herald]]'''s Free Clothing Fund, the Christian Herald Fund, and the ''[[New York Tribune]]'' Coal and Food Fund.
In 1894, the ''Journal of Social Science'' questioned the sincerity of the funds, stating that they were "managed at the caprice of their projectors", and stated that the City of New York made no increase in its appropriations to its Board of Charities and Correction in 1894, except for a small amount for coal. However, it reported that the city possessed funds totaling $2,414,283 which could have been provided to needy persons in most years. If distributed among the 50,000 people who qualified for relief, this would have averaged out to $48.30 per person. The totals took into account half of the migrant and homeless people which the journal described as ''exceptional excess'' for 1894.<ref>Kellogg, Charles D. (1894) "The Situation In New York City The Winter Of 1893-1894" ''Journal of Social Science'', volume 32, p.31.</ref>

{{Notability|Institutions|date=April 2016}} '''AIDS Housing Association of Tacoma''' (AHAT) is a 501(c)3 non-profit corporation founded in 1989 with assistance of members of Christ Church Episcopal of Tacoma and community volunteers. AHAT provides safe, alternative housing and services for people with [[HIV]]/AIDS in [[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]] and [[Kitsap County, Washington]].
AHAT (formerly known as Three Cedars) operates the only housing facilities for stage IV HIV/AIDS individuals south of King County to the Oregon border. The organization maintains three separate facilities; locations are kept anonymous for residents' privacy and security.
AHAT is a member of the [[Ryan White]] Consortium for Region V and the Coalition for the Homeless in Pierce County.
City, state and federal grants comprise the nonprofit's $530,000 budget. The organization employees ten staff. The executive director is David Strong.
==External links== ** [http://www.aidshousingtacoma.org/ AIDS Housing Association of Tacoma].

'''Abortion in [[Peru]]''' is illegal except in case of a threat to the life or health of the woman.<ref>https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2008/07/09/peru-risk-women-denied-legal-abortions</ref> A woman who consents to an abortion can be sentenced to up to two years in prison. A person who performs an illegal abortion can be sentenced to one to six years in prison.<ref name="un.org">https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/doc/peru.doc</ref>
Abortion has been generally illegal in Peru since 1924.<ref name="un.org"/>

[[File:Durham 2532.jpg|thumb|250px|Sworn virgin in Rapsha, [[Hoti (tribe)|Hoti]], Ottoman Albania at the beginning of the 20th century]]
The '''Albanian sworn virgins''' ({{lang-sq|burrnesha}}) are [[Albanians|Albanian]] women who take a vow of [[chastity]] and wear male clothing in order to live as men in the [[patriarchy|patriarchal]] northern Albanian society. National Geographic's ''[[Taboo (2002 TV series)|Taboo]]'' estimated that there are fewer than 102 [[celibacy|sworn virgins]] in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/series/taboo/0330/Overview |title=National Geographic's Taboo |publisher=natgeo.com |accessdate=2009-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117232432/http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/series/taboo/0330/Overview |archivedate=2010-01-17 |df= }}</ref>
Other terms for the sworn virgin include ''vajzë e betuar'' (most common today, and used in situations in which the parents make the decision when the girl is a baby or child), ''mashkull'' (present-day, used around Shkodra), ''virgjineshë'', ''virgjereshë'', ''verginesa'', ''virgjin'', ''vergjinesha'', ''Albanian virgin'', ''avowed virgin'', ''sadik'' (Turkish: honest, just).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Young|first=Antonia|title="Sworn Virgins": Cases of Socially Accepted Gender Change|journal=Anthropology of East Europe Review|date=December 2010|url=http://scholarworks.dlib.indiana.edu/journals/index.php/aeer/article/viewFile/687/780|pages=59–75}}</ref>
== Origins == The tradition of sworn virgins in Albania developed out of the [[Kanun (Albania)|''Kanuni i Lekë Dukagjinit'']] ({{lang-en|The Code of Lekë Dukagjini}}, or simply the ''Kanun''),<ref>From [[Turkish language|Turkish]] ''Kanun'', which means law. It is originally derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] kanôn / κανών as in [[Canon law|Canon Law]]</ref> a set of codes and laws developed by [[Lekë Dukagjini]] and used mostly in northern [[Albania]] and [[Kosovo]] from the 15th century until the 20th century. The ''Kanun'' is not a religious document – many groups follow it, including [[Albanian Orthodox]], [[Catholics]] and [[Muslim]]s.<ref name="Associated_Press_2008">{{cite web |date=October 6, 2008 |url =https://www.welt.de/english-news/article2536539/Tradition-of-sworn-virgins-dying-out-in-Albania.html|title = Tradition of sworn virgins' dying out in Albania|publisher = [[Die Welt]]| accessdate = 2008-10-22 | last=Becatoros |first=Elena | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081026144717/http://www.welt.de/english-news/article2536539/Tradition-of-sworn-virgins-dying-out-in-Albania.html| archivedate= October 26, 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The ''Kanun'' dictates that families must be patrilineal (meaning wealth is inherited through a family's men) and patrilocal (upon marriage, a woman moves into the household of her husband's family).<ref name="jolique">{{cite web |year=2008 |url = http://www.jolique.com/gender/crossing_boundaries.htm|title = Crossing Boundaries:Albania's sworn virgins|publisher = jolique| accessdate = 2008-10-07 | last= | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081018221818/http://www.jolique.com/gender/crossing_boundaries.htm| archivedate= 18 October 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Women are treated like property of the family. Under the ''Kanun'' women are stripped of many rights. They cannot smoke, wear a watch, or vote in their local elections. They cannot buy land, and there are many jobs they are not permitted to hold. There are also establishments that they cannot enter.<ref name="Associated_Press_2008"/><ref name="Washington_Post_2007">{{cite news |date=August 11, 2007|url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/10/AR2007081002158.html|title = The Sacrifices of Albania's 'Sworn Virgins'|work = [[The Washington Post]]| accessdate = 2008-10-07 | last=Zumbrun |first=Joshua}}</ref>
The practice of sworn virginhood was first reported by missionaries, travelers, geographers and anthropologists who visited the mountains of northern Albania in the 19th and early 20th centuries.<ref name="Elsie 2010 435">{{cite book|last=Elsie|first=Robert|title=Historical Dictionary of Albania|year=2010|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Lanham|isbn=0810861887|page=435|edition=2nd}}</ref>
== Overview == A woman becomes a sworn virgin by swearing an irrevocable oath, in front of twelve village or tribal elders, to practice celibacy. Then she is allowed to live as a man and may dress in male clothes, use a male name, carry a gun, smoke, drink alcohol, take on male work, act as the head of a household (for example, living with a sister or mother), play music and sing, and sit and talk socially with men.<ref name="Washington_Post_2007"/><ref name="Elsie 2010 435"/><ref name="Murray 1997 198">{{cite book|last=Murray|first=Stephen O.|title=Islamic Homosexualities: Culture, History, and Literature|year=1997|publisher=New York University Press|location=New York|isbn=0814774687|page=198|author2=Roscoe, Will |author3=Allyn, Eric }}</ref>
A woman can become a sworn virgin at any age, either to satisfy her parents or herself.<ref>{{cite book|editor-last=Magrini|editor-first=Tullia|title=Music and Gender: Perspectives from the Mediterranean|year=2003|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|isbn=0226501655|page=294}}</ref>
The sworn virgin is believed to be the only formal, socially defined [[trans man|trans masculine]] [[transgender]] and [[cross-dressing]] role in Europe. Similar practices occurred in some societies of [[indigenous peoples of the Americas]].<ref name="Elsie 2010 435"/>
Breaking the vow was once punishable by death, but it is doubtful that this punishment is still carried out.<ref name="Washington_Post_2007"/> Many sworn virgins today still refuse to go back on their oath because their community would reject them for breaking the vows.<ref name="Washington_Post_2007"/> However, it is sometimes possible to take back the vows if the sworn virgin has finished her obligations to the family and the reasons or motivations which lead her to take the vow no longer exist.
== Motivations == There are many reasons why a woman would have wanted to take this vow, and observers have recorded a variety of motivations. One woman said she became a sworn virgin in order to not be separated from her father, and another in order to live and work with her sister. Some hoped to avoid a specific unwanted marriage, and others hoped to avoid marriage in general.
Becoming a sworn virgin was the only way for women whose families had committed them as children to an [[arranged marriage]] to refuse to fulfil it, without dishonouring the groom's family and risking ''[[gjakmarrja]]'' (blood feud). It was the only way a woman could inherit her family's wealth, which was particularly important in a society in which blood feuds resulted in the deaths of many male Albanians, leaving many families without male heirs. (However, [[anthropologist]] [[Mildred Dickemann]] suggests this motive may be "over-pat", pointing out that a non-child-bearing woman would have no heirs to inherit after her, and also that in some families not one but several daughters became sworn virgins, and in others the later birth of a brother did not end the sworn virgin's masculine role.<ref name="Murray 1997 198"/>) It is also likely that many women chose to become sworn virgins simply because it afforded them much more freedom than would otherwise have been available in a patrilineal culture in which women were secluded, sex-segregated, required to be virgins before marriage and faithful afterwards, betrothed as children and married by sale without their consent, continually bearing and raising children, constantly physically labouring, and always required to defer to men, particularly their husbands and fathers, and submit to being beaten.<ref name="Associated_Press_2008"/><ref name="Elsie 2010 435"/><ref name="Murray 1997 198"/><ref name="marriage">{{cite web | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3137518.ece | title = 'Sworn virgins' dying out as Albanian girls reject manly role | author = [[David Wolman|Wolman, David]] | publisher = TimesOnline | date = January 6, 2008 | accessdate = 2008-10-08 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080906104957/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article3137518.ece| archivedate= 6 September 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Sworn virgins could also participate in blood feuds. If a sworn virgin was killed in a blood feud her death counted as a full life for the purposes of calculating [[blood money (restitution)|blood money]], rather than the half a life ordinarily accorded for a female death.<ref>{{cite book|editor-last2=Swenson|editor-first1=Sarah M. |editor-last1=Anderson |editor-first2= Karen|title=Cold Counsel: Women in Old Norse Literature and Mythology: A collection of essays|year=2002|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|isbn=0815319665|pages=50}}</ref>
Dickemann suggests their mothers may have played an important role in persuading women to become sworn virgins. A widow without sons has traditionally had few options in Albania: she could return to her birth family, stay on as a servant in the family of her deceased husband, or remarry. With a son or surrogate son, she could live out her life in the home of her adulthood, in the company of her child. Murray quotes testimony recorded by [[René Gremaux]]: "Because if you get married I'll be left alone, but if you stay with me, I'll have a son." On hearing those words Djurdja [the daughter] "threw down her embroidery" and became a man.<ref name="Murray 1997 198"/>
== Prevalence ==
The practice has died out in Dalmatia and Bosnia, but is still carried out in northern Albania and to a lesser extent in Macedonia.<ref name="Elsie 2010 435"/>
The [[Socialist People's Republic of Albania]] did not encourage women to become sworn virgins. Women started gaining legal rights and came closer to having equal social status, especially in the central and southern regions. It is only in the northern region that many families are still traditionally patriarchal.<ref name="smh_June_27_2008">{{cite web |date=June 27, 2008|url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/women-have-to-swap-genders-to-survive/2008/06/26/1214472673664.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1|title = At home with Albania's last sworn virgins|work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]]| accessdate = 2008-10-07 | last= }}</ref> Currently there are between forty and several hundred sworn virgins left in Albania, and a few in neighboring countries. Most are over fifty years old.<ref name="Associated_Press_2008"/> It used to be believed that the sworn virgins had all but died out after 50 years of communism in Albania, but recent research suggests that may not be the case;<ref name="Elsie 2010 435"/> instead, the increase in feuding following the collapse of the communist regime could encourage a resurgence of the practice.<ref name="Murray 1997 198"/>
==In popular culture == *''[[Virdžina]]'', a 1991 [[SFRJ|Yugoslav]] film based on this old custom was directed by [[Srđan Karanović]].<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0105761/ Virzina (Sworn Virgin)] on IMDB</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Canby |first=Vincent |url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9F0CEED91E3FF934A15750C0A965958260 |title=Reviews/Film Festival; A Girl Who Becomes a Boy, and Then a Woman |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref> *Italian director Laura Bispuri's first feature film, ''[[Sworn Virgin]]'', released in 2015, depicts the life of Hana, played by Italian actress [[Alba Rohrwacher]].<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/12/us-filmfestival-berlin-swornvirgin-idUSKBN0LG2IJ20150212 "Powerful film debut shows awakening of an Albanian 'Sworn Virgin'"]. Reuters. February 12, 2015. Retrieved 2015-05-03.</ref> The film is based on the novel of the same name by Albanian writer [[Elvira Dones]].<ref name="Washington_Post_2007"/> *American writer Kristopher Dukes's first novel, ''The Sworn Virgin,'' published in 2017, follows an untraditional young woman in the mountains of 1910 Albania, as her father is gunned down due to an old [[blood feud]], and she takes the vow to avoid an arranged marriage.<ref>[https://www.rtbookreviews.com/book-review/sworn-virgin "A compelling, feminist novel of a woman’s struggle to maintain her freedom and independence. Richly detailed with gripping drama, unique historical backdrops, vivid imagery"]</ref> *[[Alice Munro]], "The Albanian Virgin", [[The New Yorker]] (1992), tells the story of an English woman taken hostage who becomes an Albanian Virgin to avoid forced marriage.

'''Alejandro''' "'''Alex'''" '''Guerrero''' (born 1965)<ref name=GlobeWhoAG/> is an American [[alternative medicine]] practitioner and [[alkaline diet]] advocate. He is best known for his [[infomercials]] that contained false health claims and his work with [[Professional football (gridiron)|professional football]] players including [[Tom Brady]] and other members of the [[New England Patriots]].
==Education and early career ==
Guerrero received a [[master's degree]] in [[traditional Chinese medicine]] from Samra University in [[Los Angeles, California]], an institution that closed in 2010 after the state of California dissolved the Bureau of Private Postsecondary and Vocational Education board in 2007, which had provided the school's accreditation.<ref name=BostonMag/><ref name=Balance>{{cite book |title=In Balance for Life: Understanding & Maximizing Your Body's pH Factor |first=Alex |last=Guerrero |publisher=[[Square One Publishers|Square One]] |date=November 15, 2004 |isbn=978-0757002649}} (Aspects sourced to Introduction and About the Author sections).</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://samra.edu/ |title=Previously Samra University of Oriental Medicine |website=Former Samra University of Oriental Medicine ''official website'' |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref>
After graduating, Guerrero opened his own health treatment practice in 1996, and soon began working with individual professional athletes.<ref name=Stripped/>
==2004 book==
In 2004, Guerrero wrote a book called ''In Balance for Life: Understanding & Maximizing Your Body's pH Factor''. The book promoted what he called a "nutritional supplement program that will take your health to the next level", with a "14-Day Diet Plan to quick-start your journey to vibrant vitality".<ref name=Balance/> In the book, he said the principles of the program were "easy to understand, and even easier to implement", and said "In fact, the principles that support it have been scientifically verified time and time again by researchers throughout the world. For the most part, however, they remain all but ignored by conventional and alternative health-care providers alike. As a result, our society is increasingly burdened with health-care problems."<ref name=Balance/> The book referred to "the important role that the pH Factor plays in health and overall balance of the body" and said that "unhealthy pH levels―a disruption of proper acid-alkaline balance―are at the root of all disease conditions".<ref name=Balance/>
==Infomercials and sanctioning by the FTC==
In 2005, Guerrero was sanctioned by the [[U.S. Federal Trade Commission]] for falsely presenting himself as a doctor and claiming to be able to cure cancer, AIDS, multiple sclerosis, heart disease, diabetes, arthritis, and Parkinson's disease using a [[dietary supplement]] called "Supreme Greens".<ref name=BostonMag>{{cite web |work=[[Boston Magazine]] |url=https://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/2015/10/09/tom-brady-alex-guerrero-neurosafe/ |title=Tom Brady's Personal Guru Is a Glorified Snake-Oil Salesman |first=Chris |last=Sweeney |date=October 9, 2015 |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref> He had made these claims in [[infomercials]] on [[Spike TV]] and the [[Women's Entertainment]] channel.<ref name=BostonMag/> He claimed to have conducted extensive scientific studies of the benefits of his program with 200 patients that had been diagnosed as terminally ill before his treatments, but he later admitted that no such studies existed.<ref name=BostonMag/> The FTC fined him and barred him for life from ever again presenting himself as a doctor or from ever again marketing Supreme Greens or any substantially similar product as an effective treatment for any disease.<ref name=BostonMag/> [[Barrie Cassileth|Barrie Cassileth, Ph.D.]], the founder of the Integrative Medicine Service at the [[Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center]], who helped in the FTC investigation, referred to his practices as "just out and out quackery".<ref name=BostonMag/> She said that a major danger of such useless treatments is that they may delay patients from seeking proper [[evidence-based medicine|evidence-based medical care]], and that "this is fatal for many patients".<ref name=BostonMag/> She said "The organizations and people who make these claims and produce these false treatments really are doing something horrific."<ref name=BostonMag/>
He later founded a new company called 6 Degree Nutrition, which marketed various nutritional supplements including a product called Neurosafe. Neurosafe was called "a seatbelt for your brain", and was claimed to protect its users "from the consequences of sports-related traumatic brain injury". The product was advertised as being endorsed by prominent professional football players that had experienced concussions, with a claim that "When used consistently, NeuroSafe helps to dramatically improve recovery from head trauma by providing the brain the nutrients it needs to repair itself."<ref name=BostonMag/> [[Wes Welker]], a [[wide receiver]] who had suffered repeated concussions, was quoted as saying "NeuroSafe is essential. It keeps me safe. I've seen what concussions do to people. With NeuroSafe I know it's protecting what my helmet can't."<ref name=BostonMag/> Champion quarterback [[Tom Brady]] was quoted saying "NeuroSafe makes me feel comfortable that if I get a concussion I can recover faster and more fully. There is no other solution on the market today that can do what NeuroSafe does. It's that extra level of protection that gives me comfort when I'm out on the field."<ref name=BostonMag/> The FTC intervened again in 2012, reaching a settlement with Guerrero that resulted in closure of the company and the cessation of the marketing of the product.<ref name=BostonMag/><ref name=Investigated>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/2015/12/19/tb12-investigated/ |title=Tom Brady's TB12 Center Was Investigated by State Agencies |first=Chris |last=Sweeney |work=Boston Magazine |date=December 19, 2015 |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref>
''[[The Boston Globe]]'' reported that Guerrero also had "a long history of financial troubles, bankruptcies, and legal entanglements".<ref name=GlobeWhoAG/> He was sued twice for allegedly defrauding investors in his health product business enterprises of hundreds of thousands of dollars in investment funds, and resolved the cases with settlements under undisclosed terms.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/2015/10/23/tom-brady-alex-guerrero-fraud/ |title=Tom Brady's Guru Was Twice Sued for Fraud |first=Chris |last=Sweeney |website=Boston Magazine |date=October 23, 2015 |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref>
==Work with football players==
Guerrero has treated a number of [[Professional football (gridiron)|professional football]] players, and is especially closely associated with [[Tom Brady]], a [[quarterback]] for the [[New England Patriots]]. Brady refers to Guerrero as his "body coach" and "body engineer", and has said Guerrero "has been a huge part of what I do" and is a "huge, huge reason why I'm still playing".<ref name=GlobeWhoAG/><ref name=Stripped/> In addition to Brady, Guerrero has worked with nearly every player for the Patriots, particularly including [[Danny Amendola]], [[Jacoby Brissett]], [[Julian Edelman]], [[Jimmy Garoppolo]], [[Rob Gronkowski]], [[Duron Harmon]], [[Chris Hogan (American football)|Chris Hogan]], [[Ty Law]], and [[Willie McGinest]].<ref name=Balance/><ref name=BradyEnds>{{cite web |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nfl/tom-brady-ends-press-conference-early-after-question-about-julian-edelman-and-alex-guerrero/ar-BBLbfiF |title=Tom Brady ends press conference early after question about Julian Edelman and Alex Guerrero |via=[[MSN]] |work=[[USA Today]] |date=July 28, 2018 |access-date=July 30, 2018 |first=Lorenzo |last=Reyes}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.boston.com/sports/new-england-patriots/2017/07/31/rob-gronkowski-has-reportedly-been-following-the-tb12-method |title=Rob Gronkowski has reportedly been following the TB12 method |first=Nicole |last=Yang |work=Boston.com |date=July 31, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bostonherald.com/sports/patriots/2017/07/guregian_rob_gronkowski_adopting_training_program_of_tom_brady_and_his_guru |title=Rob Gronkowski adopting training program of Tom Brady and his guru |first=Karen |last=Guregian |work=[[The Boston Herald]] |date=July 31, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref><ref name=AroundNFL>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/sports/patriots/2017/08/17/around-nfl-qbs-are-training-and-eating-tom-brady-way/2hpOwhcZZmIBPYLXtArfkN/story.html |title=Around the NFL, QBs are training and eating the Tom Brady way |first=Ben |last=Volin |work=The Boston Globe |date=August 17, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref> In December 2017, it was estimated that Guerrero was treating about 20 of the current Patriots players.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonsportsjournal.com/2017/12/20/much-concern-alex-guerrerobill-belichick-rift-patriots/ |work=Boston Sports Journal |first=Greg A. |last=Bedard |date=December 20, 2017 |title=How much of a concern is this Alex Guerrero/Bill Belichick rift for the Patriots? |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref> The dietary and training techniques espoused by Guerrero and Brady have also been influential with other NFL players outside of the Patriots.<ref name=AroundNFL/> As in Guerrero's 2004 book, aspects of Guerrero's dietary guidelines are phrased in terms of [[pH balance]], with Brady saying he has a primarily [[alkaline diet]] that is 80 percent [[alkaline]] and 20 percent [[acidic]].<ref name=BostonMag/><ref name=AroundNFL/> The diet is mostly [[vegan]] while avoiding foods that are claimed to cause inflammation, including tomatoes, peppers, mushrooms, and eggplants.<ref name=AroundNFL/>
Earlier in his career, Guerrero also worked with [[LaDainian Tomlinson]] and [[Keenan McCardell]] of the [[San Diego Chargers]].<ref name=Balance/>
Guerrero and Brady have become collaborators and business partners in various ventures branded as "TB12" (with "TB" being the initials for Tom Brady, and 12 his jersey number as a player for the Patriots). Together they created a peak performance website TB12Sports.com and opened a facility in 2013 called the TB12 Sports Therapy Center next to [[Gillette Stadium]], the home of the New England Patriots.<ref name=BostonMag/><ref name=Stripped/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.si.com/nfl/2017/07/26/tom-brady-new-england-patriots-tb12-method |title=Living Like Tom: One Sports Illustrated Writer Takes On the TB12 Method |first=Greg |last=Bishop |date=July 26, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018 |work=[[Sports Illustrated]]}}</ref> Guerrero helped Brady develop a health program that Brady wrote about in a 2017 book, ''[[TB12|The TB12 Method]]''. Guerrero and Brady also developed "The TB12 Nutrition Manual", a line of TB12-branded snacks, protein bars, and prepared meals, and a line of TB12 workout gear and clothing (including "recovery pajamas" that are said to help the wearer recover from physical exertion and trauma).<ref name=GlobeWhoAG/><ref name=AroundNFL/> The practices of Guerrero and the TB12 Center were investigated by several Massachusetts state agencies in 2013, but the agencies took no enforcement action, partly due to regulatory exceptions granted for work that was considered [[massage therapy]].<ref name=Investigated/> In 2014, after an allegation that he was practicing [[physical therapy]] without a license, he was sent a letter instructing him to abide by state regulations when supervising the work of licensed therapists.<ref name=GlobeWhoAG/>
Although Guerrero has treated many members of the New England Patriots, there has been substantial friction with the Patriots' management and training staff over his involvement, and in December 2017, the head coach [[Bill Belichick]] and the Patriots staff stripped Guerrero of many of his team privileges.<ref name=GlobeWhoAG>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2017/12/20/who-tom-brady-friend-alex-guerrero/x45YjTMVuEiiEdH3tsX7ZO/story.html |title=Who is Tom Brady's friend Alex Guerrero? |first1=Martin |last1=Finucane |first2=Bob |last2=Hohler |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=December 20, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref><ref name=Stripped>{{cite web |url=https://www.boston.com/sports/new-england-patriots/2017/12/21/bill-belichick-alex-guerrero-tom-brady-patriots |title=A closer look at Alex Guerrero’s involvement with the Patriots |work=[[Boston.com]] |date=December 21, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018 |first=Nicole |last=Yang}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.boston.com/sports/new-england-patriots/2017/10/31/10-things-we-learned-from-espns-timely-tom-brady-story-on-nfl-longevity |title=10 things we learned from ESPN's timely story on Tom Brady's longevity |date=October 31, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018 |work=Boston.com |first=Hayden |last=Bird}}</ref>
Dr. Jessica Flynn, a specialist in [[sports medicine]] at the [[Lahey Hospital & Medical Center]], criticized Guerrero's practices in 2017, saying that although she truly believes "there is a lot of good going on at TB12", she is troubled that Guerrero has implied that doctors don't really care about the functional outcomes for their athletic patients.<ref name=DoctorAim/> In an otherwise-positive account of one writer's experience, Guerrero had reportedly told his patient that "your surgeon's number one goal is to protect his surgery site. He doesn't care if you ever run again. He doesn't care if you want to climb Mount Everest."<ref name=DoctorAim/> Moreover, Flynn said she is concerned that at TB12 "they continue to profit from non-proven treatments, supplements, and other therapies and none of those profits seem to be invested in studying their efficacy."<ref name=DoctorAim>{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonmagazine.com/health/2017/05/08/jessica-flynn-alex-guerrero/ |first=Jamie |last=Ducharme |work=Boston Magazine |date=May 8, 2017 |access-date=July 30, 2018 |title=Boston Doctor Takes Aim at Tom Brady's Health Guru}}</ref> She said "Guerrero functions in a different world than doctors. He doesn't have to prove his therapies work, or even that they are safe."<ref name=DoctorAim/>
In an article on the sports website ''[[Deadspin]]'', the sports writer Tom Ley used even more harsh language. He called Guerrero a "dangerous quack guru" and said "In a just world, Guerrero would be shunned from public life and quickly identified as a scam artist who has preyed on desperate and even dying people when making any attempt to present himself as a credible fitness guru."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://deadspin.com/sports-illustrated-nakedly-shills-for-tom-bradys-danger-1797276280 |first=Tom |last=Ley |title=''Sports Illustrated'' Nakedly Shills For Tom Brady's Dangerous Quack Guru |date=July 26, 2017 |website=[[Deadspin]] |access-date=July 30, 2018}}</ref>
In July 2018, Guerrero became the subject of inquiries about his association with the receiver [[Julian Edelman]], and Edelman's suspension for using [[performance-enhancing drugs]]. Guerrero issued a statement saying "Here at our facility, we take a natural, holistic, appropriate and, above all, legal approach to training and recovery for all of our clients. And anyone who would suggest otherwise is irresponsible, and just plain wrong."<ref name=BradyEnds/> When a reporter said to Brady that a lot of people thought Edelman's violation might be connected to Guerrero, Brady said "It's just ridiculous. I'm out. See you guys," and abruptly ended the press conference.<ref name=BradyEnds/> Brady reacted similarly a month later when asked about Guerrero in late August. During a weekly interview segment that Brady regularly held with [[WEEI-FM|WEEI]] radio, Brady was asked about whether Guerrero was traveling with the team and about the relationship between Guerrero and team management. Brady said he didn't want to talk in detail about the topic, and when the reporter asked follow-up questions, he said "Yeah. Alright, guys. Have a great day. I'll talk to you later," and hung up the phone.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/patriots/2018/08/27/tom-brady-radio-interview-alex-guerrero-questions/1108341002/ |title=Tom Brady abruptly ends radio interview after repeated questions about trainer Alex Guerrero |first=Tom |last=Schad |work=[[USA Today]] |date=August 27, 2018 |access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/columnist/martin-rogers/2018/08/27/why-does-tom-brady-refuse-answer-questions-alex-guerrero/1113943002/ |title=Why does Tom Brady refuse to answer questions about Alex Guerrero? |first=Martin |last=Rogers |work=[[USA Today]] |date=August 27, 2018 |access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-tom-brady-guerrero-20180827-story.html |title=Tom Brady cuts another interview short after questions about personal trainer Alex Guerrero |first=Chuck |last=Schilken |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=August 27, 2018 |access-date=August 27, 2018}}</ref>

'''Anne O'Tate''' is a free, web-based application <ref name="cite pmid| 18279519">{{Cite journal | last1 = Smalheiser | first1 = N. R. | last2 = Zhou | first2 = W. | last3 = Torvik | first3 = V. I. | title = Anne O'Tate: A tool to support user-driven summarization, drill-down and browsing of PubMed search results | doi = 10.1186/1747-5333-3-2 | journal = Journal of Biomedical Discovery and Collaboration | volume = 3 | pages = 2 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18279519 | pmc =2276193 }}</ref> that analyses sets of records identified on [[PubMed]], the [[bibliographic database]] of articles from over 5,500 biomedical journals worldwide. While PubMed has its own wide range of search options to identify sets of records relevant to a researchers query it lacks the ability to analyse these sets of records further, a process for which the terms [[text mining]] and [[drill down]] have been used. Anne O'Tate is able to perform such analysis and can process sets of up to 25,000 PubMed records.<ref name="cite pmid| 18279519"/>
==Description==
Once a set of articles has been identified using Anne O’Tate with its PubMed-like interface and search syntax, the set can be analysed and words and concepts mentioned in specific 'fields' (sections) of PubMed records can be displayed in order of frequency.<ref name="cite pmid| 20333611 ">{{Cite journal | last1 = Palidwor | first1 = G. A. | last2 = Andrade-Navarro | first2 = M. A. | title = MLTrends: Graphing MEDLINE term usage over time | journal = Journal of biomedical discovery and collaboration | volume = 5 | pages = 1–6 | year = 2010 | pmid = 20333611 | pmc = 2990277 }}</ref> ‘Fields’ which Anne O’Tate can display in this manner are:
===Topics (MeSH)=== This option may help to identify possible [[Medical Subject Headings]] (known as MeSH terms, but called ‘Topics’ by Anne O’Tate) for a subject for which no corresponding subject heading or ‘entry term’ (cross-references to preferred MeSH term) exists or where PubMed’s automatic mapping process (identifying a MeSH term and including it in a search formulation) fails.
Searching for instance for articles on ‘“Knowledge Transfer”’ (for which no correspending MeSH or entry term exists) will retrieve a set of some 530 studies in PubMed (as of August 2011); Anne O’Tate’s analysis suggests that MeSH terms like "Diffusion of Innovation" or "Information Dissemination" may be suitable additional concepts to retrieve a more ‘sensitive’ (comprehensive) set of references. This method of identifying possible MeSH terms is not available on PubMed.
===Authors=== This option may help with identifying authors who have written frequently about a given subject, or may help with identifying possible experts or peer reviewers
===Journals=== Identifying journals which publish papers on the subject under investigation may assist with selecting suitable journals to consider for manuscripts or for detailed scanning for relevant articles ('hand searching'<ref name="cite pmid| 10381991">{{Cite journal | last1 = Langham | first1 = J. | last2 = Thompson | first2 = E. | last3 = Rowan | first3 = K. | title = Identification of randomized controlled trials from the emergency medicine literature: Comparison of hand searching versus MEDLINE searching | journal = Annals of Emergency Medicine | volume = 34 | issue = 1 | pages = 25–34 | year = 1999 | pmid = 10381991 | doi=10.1016/s0196-0644(99)70268-4 }}</ref>) not found by the search on PubMed.
===Other fields=== Author affiliations (addresses) and the years of publication can also be analysed. ‘Important words’ from titles and abstracts which may "[...] have more frequent occurrences in the result subset than in the [[MEDLINE]] as a whole, thus they distinguish the result subset from the rest of MEDLINE" <ref name="cite pmid| 21245076">{{Cite journal | last1 = Lu | first1 = Z. | doi = 10.1093/database/baq036 | title = PubMed and beyond: A survey of web tools for searching biomedical literature | journal = Database | volume = 2011 | pages = baq036–baq036 | year = 2011 | pmid = 21245076 | pmc =3025693 }}</ref> can be identified and help with further refining a search on PubMed.<ref name="cite pmid| 8563319">{{Cite journal | last1 = Wilczynski | first1 = N. L. | last2 = Walker | first2 = C. J. | last3 = McKibbon | first3 = K. A. | last4 = Haynes | first4 = R. B. | title = Reasons for the loss of sensitivity and specificity of methodologic MeSH terms and textwords in MEDLINE | journal = Proceedings / the ... Annual Symposium on Computer Application [sic] in Medical Care. Symposium on Computer Applications in Medical Care | pages = 436–440 | year = 1995 | pmid = 8563319 | pmc = 2579130 }}</ref><ref name="cite pmid| 9251552">{{Cite journal | last1 = Greenhalgh | first1 = T. | title = How to read a paper. The Medline database | journal = BMJ (Clinical research ed.) | volume = 315 | issue = 7101 | pages = 180–183 | year = 1997 | pmid = 9251552 | pmc = 2127107 | doi=10.1136/bmj.315.7101.180 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Smalheiser | first1 = N. R. | last2 = Zhou | first2 = W. | last3 = Torvik | first3 = V. I. | doi = 10.3390/info2020266 | title = Distribution of "Characteristic" Terms in MEDLINE Literatures | journal = Information | volume = 2 | issue = 4 | pages = 266–276 | year = 2011 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
== History ==
Anne O'Tate (a pun on the word ‘annotate’) was developed by Neil R Smalheiser and a team of researchers from the [[University of Chicago]]. It is part of the Arrowsmith Project, which developed tools such as “Arrowsmith” proper, a text-comparison application,<ref name="cite pmid| 19185946">{{Cite journal | last1 = Smalheiser | first1 = N. R. | last2 = Torvik | first2 = V. I. | last3 = Zhou | first3 = W. | doi = 10.1016/j.cmpb.2008.12.006 | title = Arrowsmith two-node search interface: A tutorial on finding meaningful links between two disparate sets of articles in MEDLINE | journal = Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine | volume = 94 | issue = 2 | pages = 190–197 | year = 2009 | pmid = 19185946 | pmc =2693227 }}</ref> "Adam", a database of medical abbreviations,<ref name="cite pmid| 16982707">{{Cite journal | last1 = Zhou | first1 = W. | last2 = Torvik | first2 = V. I. | last3 = Smalheiser | first3 = N. R. | doi = 10.1093/bioinformatics/btl480 | title = ADAM: Another database of abbreviations in MEDLINE | journal = Bioinformatics | volume = 22 | issue = 22 | pages = 2813–2818 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16982707 | pmc = }}</ref> and ‘’Author-ity’’ (an author-disambiguation tool),<ref name="cite pmid| 20072710">{{Cite journal | last1 = Torvik | first1 = V. I. | last2 = Smalheiser | first2 = N. R. | title = Author Name Disambiguation in MEDLINE | journal = ACM Transactions on Knowledge Discovery from Data | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | year = 2009 | pmid = 20072710 | pmc = 2805000 }}</ref> "Compendium", a list of [[biomedical text mining]] tools, and Anne O’Tate. The Project is based on research led by [[Don R. Swanson]] at the [[University of Chicago]] <ref>{{cite journal |journal= Library Trends |volume= 48 |number= 1 |date= Summer 1999 |pages= 48–59 |title= Implicit Text Linkages between Medline Records: Using Arrowsmith as an Aid to Scientific Discovery |author1= Swanson, D.R. |author2= Smalheiser, N.R. |url= http://www.ideals.illinois.edu/bitstream/handle/2142/8269/librarytrendsv48i1e_opt.pdf |accessdate= July 4, 2011 }}</ref> which hosted the original tool.<ref>{{cite web |title= Arrowsmith-2 on Linux |url= http://kiwi.uchicago.edu/ |publisher= The University of Chicago |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090618051959/http://kiwi.uchicago.edu/ |archivedate= June 18, 2009 |accessdate= July 4, 2011 }}</ref> Further research was led by Neil R. Smalheiser at the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]], with funding from the [[National Institutes of Health]].<ref>{{cite conference |pages= 26–43 |conference=8th international conference on discovery science |date= October 2005 |author= Smalheiser, N.R. |isbn=978-3-540-29230-2 |title=Discovery Science |volume=3735 |chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lbfHJWW8NtkC&pg=PA26 |doi=10.1007/11563983_5 |chapter=The Arrowsmith Project: 2005 Status Report |series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science}}</ref>
==Other PubMed text-mining applications==
A wide range of text-mining applications for PubMed have been developed,<ref name="cite pmid| 21245076"/> using their own interface, such as [[GoPubMed]], ClusterMed, or PubReMiner. Only Anne O’Tate uses PubMed’s standard interface, search syntax, and some of its functionality.

{{Infobox holiday | |holiday_name = Autism Sunday |image = AutismSunday01.jpg |caption = The International Day of Prayer for [[autism spectrum disorder]]s |week_ordinal = second |weekday = Sunday |month = February |frequency = annual |duration = 1 day }} '''Autism Sunday''', also known as the '''International Day of Prayer for [[autism spectrum disorder]]s''', is an event observed annually on the second Sunday of February.
==History== Autism Sunday was first held in 2002 during Autism Awareness Year in the [[United Kingdom]]. It was initiated by parents and carers [[Ivan Corea (Autism Campaign and Journalist)|Ivan Corea]] and Charika Corea, founders of the [[Autism Awareness Campaign UK]]. Parents of Charin, a teenager with [[autism spectrum disorder]] and a [[communication disorder]], they urged leaders of religious organisations, churches, community groups and world leaders around the globe to speak up for people with autism spectrum disorders.<ref name="Speak Up for Autism">{{cite web |title= Autism Sunday - Church Leaders Urged to Speak Out (BBC) |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/collective/A31933415 |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-12-19}}</ref>
[[Image:London St. Paul's Cathedral.jpg#file|thumb|150px|The first-ever service for Autism Sunday was held at [[St.Paul's Cathedral]], [[London]] in 2002 Autism Awareness Year, UK, initiated by parents and carers [[Ivan Corea (Autism Campaign and Journalist)|Ivan Corea]] and Charika Corea.]] The first service for autism was held in February 2002 at [[St Paul's Cathedral]] in London. Former Education Ministers, peers from the [[House of Lords]], celebrities, writers, broadcasters, and the media joined children and people at St Paul's Cathedral to pray for children and adults with autism spectrum disorders, as well as their parents and caregivers.
In 2008, the first [[Early Day Motion]] on Autism Sunday was tabled in the House of Commons, in the [[Palace of Westminster]]. The motion, EDM 874, was sponsored by [[David Drew (MP)|David Drew]] MP and signed by 71 members of Parliament. It calls on the Government to work with all faith communities in order to reach out to parents, caregivers and people with autism spectrum disorders in local communities, and urges church leaders and community groups of all denominations to engage with people with autism spectrum disorders.<ref name="EDM 874 on Autism Sunday">{{cite web |title= Autism Sunday - Early Day Motion 874 in the House of Commons (UK Parliament) |url=http://edmi.parliament.uk/edmi/EDMDetails.aspx?EDMID=35050&SESSION=891|year=2008 |accessdate=2008-12-19}}</ref> The British Prime Minister, [[David Cameron]] extended his personal support for Autism Sunday.<ref name=British>{{cite web |title=Prime Minister David Cameron on Autism Sunday|url=http://autismsunday.blog.co.uk/2011/01/13/prime-minister-david-cameron-on-autism-sunday-10360767/|year=2011 |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref>
==Debate in the House of Commons== Autism Sunday was mentioned in a debate in the House of Commons in the British Parliament. [[David Taylor (Labour politician)|David Taylor]] MP mentioned the day and called for action stating that the "Churches and other religious organisations will be supporting an international day of prayer for those with autism and Asperger's syndrome. Will the Leader of the House take this as a bid as a topical debate on the issue, which affects hundreds of thousands of people throughout the country? The conditions are under-recognised and under-resourced and they badly need a national strategy, a national task force and a well resourced plan for the future." <ref name="David Taylor MP on Autism Sunday">{{cite web |title= David Taylor MP on Autism Sunday in a debate in the House of Commons (UK Parliament) |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmhansrd/cm080207/debtext/80207-0006.htm|year=2008 |accessdate=2008-12-19}}</ref>
In reply, the Leader of the Commons,(at the time) [[Harriet Harman]] MP said: "For many years, families have struggled to support and care for children with autism, often to a great extent on their own and without the proper back-up of integrated services. There is now a great deal more awareness of the difficulties of autism and Asperger’s syndrome, and a recognition of the importance of early diagnosis and integrated services. I congratulate the Churches on picking this for an international day of prayer, and we would like to work with the Churches, local government and the [[voluntary sector]] to ensure that families with a family member who develops autism or Asperger’s have the backing that they need in future." <ref name="Harriet Harman MP on Autism Sunday">{{cite web |title= Harriet Harman MP, Leader of the Commons on Autism Sunday in a debate in the House of Commons (UK Parliament) |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmhansrd/cm080207/debtext/80207-0006.htm|year=2008 |accessdate=2008-12-19}}</ref>
==International Day of Prayer for Autism spectrum disorders== [[File:Mina San José - Los 33 in the Blue Room at Presidential Palace with President and First Lady - Gobierno de Chile.jpg|thumb|150px|Chilean Miner Jose Henriquez, standing second from right,here with the [[President of Chile]] and the 33 rescued miners - Henriquez sent a special message of support for Autism Sunday 2011 and was presented with his first autism awareness ribbon - during his UK tour in January 2011.]] [[File:Autism awareness ribbon-20051114.png#file|thumb|150px|Autism Awareness Ribbons are worn on Autism Sunday.]] Churches of all denominations around the world now honor the millions of people with autism on Autism Sunday, the International Day of Prayer for autism spectrum disorders.<ref name=AutismSunday>{{cite web |title= Autism Sunday |url=http://autismsunday.tripod.com/ |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-02-02}}</ref> Organisers estimate there are 60 million people with autism around the world.<ref name=AutismSunday/> Campaigners have said that many suffer without proper public services in education, health, specialist speech therapy and respite care in several parts of the world, particularly in [[Africa]] and [[Asia]]. The credit crunch and the global recession which hit many countries in 2008-2009 also affected the Autism Community. In the UK, people were concerned about the cuts to disability benefits and cuts to public services. Homes were re-possessed during the economic downturn and some families below the poverty line had to choose between heating and eating.<ref name=heating>{{cite web |title= MPs call for urgent action on Autism and Winter Fuel Poverty|url=http://www.bloggernews.net/119059 |year=2008 |accessdate=2009-01-24| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090103191243/http://www.bloggernews.net/119059| archivedate= 3 January 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
World church leaders have been supporting Autism Sunday. [[Pope Benedict XVI]] told the organisers that he would be praying for the autism community on Autism Sunday.<ref name=Pope>{{cite web |title=Pope to Pray for People with Autism on Autism Sunday 2009 |url=http://autismsunday.blog.co.uk/2009/01/26/pope-to-pray-for-people-with-autism-on-autism-sunday-5453068/|year=2009 |accessdate=2009-01-26}}</ref> Some of the largest churches in the United States, including [[Rick Warren]]'s [[Saddleback Church]], have pledged to pray for over 60 million people with autism spectrum disorders on Autism Sunday. Support came from the [[Bishop of London]] in the United Kingdom, Rt.Rev.[[Richard Chartres]].<ref name= World>{{cite web |title=Autism Sunday: World Church Leaders send messages of support|url=http://www.bloggernews.net/119578|year=2009 |accessdate=2009-01-31| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090202051235/http://www.bloggernews.net/119578| archivedate= 2 February 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The organizers have urged parents, carers and the worldwide Autism Community to use no Autism Sunday as a platform to lobby and campaign on the serious issues.<ref name= platform>{{cite web |title=Autism Sunday 2011|url=http://autismsunday.blog.co.uk/2011/01/13/autism-sunday-10360182/|year=2011 |accessdate=2011-01-16}}</ref> Support for Autism Sunday 2011 came from the Chilean Miner, Jose Henriquez, the 24th miner to be rescued from the San Jose mine. Henriquez was invited by US President [[Barack Obama]] to address the Presidential Prayer Breakfast in February 2011. He met [[Ivan Corea (Autism Campaign and Journalist)|Ivan Corea]] and Charika Corea, the Founders of Autism Sunday in the UK, prior to his departure to [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name= JoseHenriquez>{{cite web |title=Chilean Miner Jose Henriquez presented with autism ribbon to mark Autism Sunday 2011|url=http://ukautismnews.blog.co.uk/2011/01/30/chilean-miner-jose-henriquez-presented-with-autism-ribbon-to-mark-autism-sunday-10465070/|year=2011 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> They presented him with his first-ever [[autism]] awareness ribbon. The news of the presentation was relayed by the media in Chile.<ref name=autismribbons >{{cite web |title=Autism ribbons presented to miner Jose Henriquez|url=http://www.ilovechile.cl/2011/02/01/autism-ribbons-presented-to-miner-jose-henriquez/16694|year=2011 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Jose Henriquez released a special message in support of Autism Sunday 2011.<ref name= message>{{cite web |title=Jose Henriquez the Chilean Miner sends a special message for Autism Sunday 2011|url=http://www.bloggernews.net/126000|year=2011 |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
